definition: to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-
gas/air/smell/weather/to make angry/to annoy/to get angry/vital energy/qi

sentences.english: The smoke almost choked the fireman.
sentences.chinese: 消防队员几乎被烟熏得透不过气来。

sentences.english: Which ONE of the following brand is link to obsolete?
sentences.chinese: 以下哪一个手提电话品牌令你联想是过气？

sentences.english: The room was so stuffy that one could hardly breathe.
sentences.chinese: 屋里太闷，憋得人透不过气来。

sentences.english: The baby couldn't breathe because its nose was congested.
sentences.chinese: 婴儿鼻子塞住，透不过气来。

sentences.english: China is literally choking on their environmental disaster.
sentences.chinese: 中国在环境灾害上确实透不过气来。

sentences.english: As many people are smoking here , I am unable to breathe because of the smoke.
sentences.chinese: 许多人在这里抽烟，所以我被烟呛得透不过气来。

sentences.english: To choke or gasp, as in swallowing large amounts of liquid.
sentences.chinese: 噎住或透不过气来，如在吞下大量液体的时候。

sentences.english: He has a feeling of tightness in the chest or a feeling that he is suffocating.
sentences.chinese: 他胸部觉得闷闷的，好像透不过气来。

sentences.english: Another Western shibboleth about the future will thereby fall.
sentences.chinese: 另一个西方对未来的过气观点也会因此陨落。

sentences.english: He was famously a fan of the superannuated British rockers Deep Purple.
sentences.chinese: 众所周知他是过气的英国摇滚乐队“深紫”的粉丝。

sentences.english: The polluted air from the factory almost choked me.
sentences.chinese: 工厂里放出来的污染的大气呛得我几乎透不过气来。

sentences.english: I would be ground down between the Congress and the increasingly assertive bureaucracy.
sentences.chinese: 我将被国会和日益武断的官僚机构压挤得透不过气来。

sentences.english: I went out of the meeting room; the atmosphere there smothered me.
sentences.chinese: 我走出了会议室，那里的气氛令我透不过气来。

sentences.english: That politician is already a has-been.
The tense atmosphere made everybody suffocate.
sentences.chinese: 大家都被这紧张的气氛搞得透不过气来。

sentences.english: The smoke has almost smothered me.
sentences.chinese: 那烟闷得我几乎透不过气来。

definition: currently popular (of movie stars, singers etc)
to make one's name/to become famous
a while/a spell/a short time/a burst
wind direction/the way the wind blows/fig. trend/direction of events/how things develop (esp. how they affect oneself)/public opinion (concerning one's actions)/publicity (usually derog.)/limelight
returning to our main topic,.../that said,.../again,.../in this connection/in passing/nevertheless,.../anyhow
to make one's first public performance (of an entertainer etc)/to start one's career
It is said that ... (at the start of a narrative)/to discuss/to recount
to become suddenly popular/suddenly all the rage
